newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power up on warmer weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power up on warmer weather.

text.p: Spot electricity prices in the U.S. Mid-Atlantic rose Wednesday on outlook of warmer weather moving into the region next week, market sources said.
"The six to 10 day forecast showed much warmer weather up into Maine," said a Houston trader.
A few participants were skeptical how large an increase in power demand clearer skies and higher temperatures would bring.
"We don't expect any more load," said one regional utility trader, adding that the price rise may be more associated with idling of some fossil-fueled palnts for the weekend.

He noted utilities often plan to idle a certain amount of "baseload" generation or shift it to "peak" status over the weekend when it is considered more expensive to operate on a marginal basis during low-load periods.

In the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) Interconnect power pool, electricity prices for firm, peak delivery on Thursday were assessed at $20.25-$22.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), a wider range than Tuesday's $21.00-$21.50 range.
Firm PJM power for light load hours on Thursday was quoted at $13.00-$13.25, compared with Tuesday's $13.25.
PJM firm, peak electricity for next two days was valued at $20.25-$21.25, up from Tuesday's $20.00-$20.50 range.
Peak, firm power for the balance of September was discussed at $19.75-$20.75, up from Tuesday's $19.50 area, with unconfirmed deals done today at $20.25 and $20.50.
October firm, peak PJM electricity was quoted at $20.40-$20.50, narrower than Tuesday's $20.00-$20.50.
November PJM power was pegged at $21.50-$21.60, tighter than $21.45-$21.70 on Tuesday. December PJM was assessed at $25.40-$25.50, better bid than Tuesday's $25.00-$25.50 range.
PJM delivery in the 1996 fourth-quarter was quoted at $22.40-$22.60, tighter than a range of $22.30-$22.60 on Tuesday.
January/February 1997 PJM power was valued at $29.20-$29.35, with a trade last reported at $29.25.
